title: What is the intermolecular force of PH4? - Quora

response.answer_text: PH4+ (phosphonium) is a cation where negative ions can form salts similarly to NH4+ (ammonium). You can look at NH4+ to see how it reacts. However, there is a major difference: NH4+ has the electrons more likely to be found in the N atom than the 4 H’s. This is because N’s electronegativity is high enough for this to occur (only N, O, and F have this). P’s electronegativity is almost equal to H’s. This means that electrons are evenly spread. There won’t be particularly strong ion bonds compared to NH4+’s because of the absence of H’s that are electron-deprived (giving them a partial positive charge to attract to the negatively charged anion). This means that PH4Br is not as strongly bonded as NH4Br, for example, but I’d bet it’s still a fairly strong ion bond.
